title: Sara Kingsley
text: Seasons greetings Carnegie Mellon community, I am available for meetings by appointment. Please send an email from your Andrew or organizational email to schedule.

title: Sara Kingsley
text:
Research Work:
My research specifically focuses on understanding the economic and cybersecurity risks of Machine Learning and AI systems and tools, focusing on transformer or generative AI models and agent systems.
I study this research topic by modifying existing methods for auditing – as well as developing novel methods for evaluating – machine learning or AI systems. This includes transferring data science and computational social science methods to the identification of AI Cyber and Economic Security Threats.
At this time, this work often involves `red-teaming’ generative AI models, including for industry partners.

title: Sara Kingsley
text:
Red-teaming Inquiries:
To inquire about my availability to join your organization’s red-team, please send an email to <sara[@]redteamai.org>

title: Sara Kingsley
text:
News:

August 2025: I am a teaching faculty at Carnegie Mellon University and an AI Security Researcher.
August 2025: I earned my PhD from Carnegie Mellon University’s School of Computer Science.

title: Email Your Boss ChatBot
text: This is version 1. It is buggy FYI.

title: Email Your Boss ChatBot
section: Where can I find the Chatbot?
text:
Where can I find the Chatbot?
Press the blue button at the bottom of the screen to open the ChatBot.

title: Email Your Boss ChatBot
text:
Instructions
The ChatBot will only take 2 user inputs/messages and provide only 2 responses to those inputs, then the conversation will end.
If you want to generate additional AI generated responses, please press “Start New Chat.” Then you will have 2 more inputs and responses, etc. and so on.

What Prompts should I provide?
Imagine you are a new employee or job-seeker. Your (prospective) boss has given you a general or ambiguous job description or task to do. You’d like feedback on how, when (etc.) your (prospective) boss would like the task done. You’re unsure how to compose an email to ask. Describe the job description or task to the ChatBot. Would you send this email to your boss? Yes? No? Why or why not?


Note
We have found the connection to Voiceflow buggy. If the chatBot doesn’t respond, please start a new chat and try again. If that doesn’t work, wait 10-15 minutes, and it will usually work at some point.
This is about the most basic prototype we could make. We are working to add more interaction types and resolve the connection issues and bugs.

title: Email Your Boss ChatBot
text:
Feedback
We’d love your feedback! Please send any feedback or questions to Sara Kingsley at <skingsle [at] cs.cmu.edu>

title: Research
text: A complete list of my peer-reviewed (both non-archival and archival) publications are listed on this page.

title: Research
text:
Archival

Rena Li, Sara Kingsley, Chelsea Fan, Proteeti Sinha, Nora Wai, Jaimie Lee, Hong Shen, Motahhare Eslami, and Jason I. Hong. 2023. “Participation and Division of Labor in User-Driven Algorithm Audits: How Do Everyday Users Work together to Surface Algorithmic Harms?.” In the Proceedings of ACM’s Conference on Human Factors in Computing (CHI). Forthcoming, April 2023, Hamburg, Germany. [Pre-print paper link] (https://sarakingsley.github.io/twitterpaperindex.html) *** Equal contributions
Sara Kingsley, Proteeti Sinha, Clara Wang, Motahhare Eslami, and Jason I. Hong. 2022. “Give Everybody [..] a Little Bit More Equity”: Content Creator Perspectives and Responses to the Algorithmic Demonetization of Content Associated with Disadvantaged Groups.” Proc. ACM Hum.-Comput. Interact. 6, CSCW2, Article 424 (November 2022), 37 pages. ACM Library
Shamika Klassen, Sara Kingsley, Kalyn McCall, Joy Weinberg, and Casey Fiesler. 2022. Black Lives, Green Books, and Blue Checks: Comparing the Content of the Negro Motorist Green Book to the Content on Black Twitter. Proc. ACM Hum.-Comput. Interact. 6, GROUP, Article 27 (January 2022), 22 pages. ACM Library
Shamika Klassen, Sara Kingsley, Kalyn McCall, Joy Weinberg, and Casey Fiesler. 2021. More than a Modern Day Green Book: Exploring the Online Community of Black Twitter. Proc. ACM Hum.-Comput. Interact. 5, CSCW2, Article 458 (October 2021), 29 pages. ACM Library
Rediet Abebe, Kehinde Aruleba, Abeba Birhane, Sara Kingsley, George Obaido, Sekou L. Remy, and Swathi Sadagopan.* 2021. Narratives and Counternarratives on Data Sharing in Africa. In Proceedings of the 2021 ACM Conference on Fairness, Accountability, and Transparency (FAccT ’21). Association for Computing Machinery, New York, NY, USA, 329–341. ACM Library
Sara Kingsley, Mary L. Gray and Siddharth Suri. “Accounting for Market Frictions and Power Asymmetries in Online Labor Markets,” Policy & Internet, 2015, 7 (4), 383-400. Policy & Internet

title: Research
text:
Non-archival
These publications were peer-reviewed by a non-publishing venue. I have posted these publications here via arXiv, SSRN and institutional press.

Sara Kingsley, Clara Wang, Alexandra Mikhalenko, Proteeti Sinha and Chinmay Kulkarni. “Auditing Digital Platforms for Discrimination in Economic Opportunity Advertising.” In the Proceedings of ACM Economics and Computation 4th Workshop on Mechanism Design for Social Good (MD4SG 20), June 2019: Phoenix, Arizona. arXiv
Abhishek Gupta, Camylle Lanteigne and Sara Kingsley. “SECure: A Social and Environmental Certificate for AI Systems.” In the Proceedings of ACM Economics and Computation 4th Workshop on Mechanism Design for Social Good (MD4SG 20), June 2019: Phoenix, Arizona. arXiv
Sara Kingsley, Mary L. Gray and Siddharth Suri. “Monopsony and the crowd: labor for lemons?” Conference on Internet, Policy &. Policy (IPP), September 2014: Oxford Internet Institute, Oxford University, Oxford. Oxford University

title: Research

title: Research
text:
